## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME (Parker Solar Probe)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2023-04-30T20:09:13Z
## Message ID: 20230430-AL-003
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2023-04-30T08:36Z.

Estimated speed: ~870 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 14 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 116/-19 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2023-04-30T08:36:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact Parker Solar Probe (glancing blow).  The flank of the CME will reach Parker Solar Probe at 2023-05-02T14:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME: 2023-04-30T08:36:00-CME-001):

http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20230430_130800_2.0_anim.tim-den.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20230430_130800_2.0_anim.tim-vel.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20230430_130800_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20230430_130800_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_PSP_timeline.gif


## Notes: 


SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2023-04-30T15:33:26Z
## Message ID: 20230430-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux remains elevated, recently crossing the threshold of 1000 pfu at 2023-04-30T07:50Z.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels observed since 2023-04-26T12:35Z (see notifications 20230426-AL-001, 20230426-AL-002, and 20230428-AL-002) are likely caused by the arrival of CME with ID 2023-04-21T18:12:00-CME-001 (see notifications 20230423-AL-006, 20230423-AL-008, and 20230423-AL-009, 20230423-AL-011, and 20230424-AL-001) and possibly a coronal hole high speed stream which arrived on 2023-04-26. The solar wind reached a maximum speed of approximately 710 km/s and is currently around 495 km/s.

The arrival of the CME with ID 2023-04-21T18:12:00-CME-001 was detected at L1 by DSCOVR and ACE at 2023-04-23T17:00Z (see notification 20230423-AL-006) and simulations indicated that the magnetopause separating magnetospheric and solar wind plasma was close to the geosynchronous orbit starting at 2023-04-23T19:15Z (see notifications 20230423-AL-008 and 20230423-AL-009). This arrival was associated with a geomagnetic storm reaching a maximum Kp index level of 8 (severe) (see notifications 20230423-AL-011 and 20230424-AL-001).

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2023-04-26T12:35:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes:

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME update (ensemble) (STEREO A, Missions Near Earth)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2023-04-30T12:46:41Z
## Message ID: 20230430-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

BETA PRODUCT. ENSEMBLE PRODUCT IS STILL IN DEVELOPMENT MODE. PLEASE LET US KNOW IF YOU HAVE ANY SUGGESTIONS FOR MODIFICATIONS.  

Ensemble modeling update on CME with ID 2023-04-29T02:23:00-CME-001 (see previous notification 20230429-AL-001). Based on analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric ensemble modeling carried out at the Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact STEREO A. For 40 ensemble members (see notes section), simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach:

- STEREO A between about 2023-05-01T14:22Z and 2023-05-02T11:00Z (average arrival 2023-05-01T23:46Z) for 97% of simulations.

Additionally the CME is estimated to reach NASA missions near Earth between about 2023-05-01T17:11Z and 2023-05-02T14:39Z (average arrival 2023-05-02T02:41Z) for 97% of simulations.  The ensemble-based forecast indicates that there is a 73% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 3-5 range (below minor to minor).

Links to the ensemble details of the modeled event:
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-04-29_ncmes1_sims40_HILOX175/20230429_022300_ncmes1_sims40_HILOX175_anim_tim-den.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-04-29_ncmes1_sims40_HILOX175/20230429_022300_ncmes1_sims40_HILOX175_arrival_Earth.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-04-29_ncmes1_sims40_HILOX175/20230429_022300_ncmes1_sims40_HILOX175_Earth_stack.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-04-29_ncmes1_sims40_HILOX175/20230429_022300_ncmes1_sims40_HILOX175_probabilistic_Kp_forecast_wdist.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-04-29_ncmes1_sims40_HILOX175/20230429_022300_ncmes1_sims40_HILOX175_arrival_STA.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-04-29_ncmes1_sims40_HILOX175/20230429_022300_ncmes1_sims40_HILOX175_STA_stack.gif

## Notes:
This CME event (2023-04-29T02:23:00-CME-001) is also predicted to give a glancing blow to OSIRIS-REx at 2023-05-02T19:00Z (plus minus 7 hours) based on previous heliospheric modeling (see notification 20230429-AL-001).

Ensemble CME modeling at M2M is performed by building sets of initial CME parameters and carrying out separate simulations for each set. This approach allows a mapping of initial CME parameter uncertainties into a statistical characterization of CME arrival times and impact at locations of interest.

Description of links: For each location, the first link shows the WSA-ENLIL+Cone model animation for the median CME input parameters, the second link shows the probabilistic distribution of predicted arrival times histogram, and the third link shows a stack plot of the WSA-ENLIL+Cone modeled magnetic field, velocity, density, and temperature for all ensemble members. For missions near Earth, a histogram of the probabilistic Kp forecast is also provided.

For the full details of the modeled event, please go here:
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-04-29_ncmes1_sims40_HILOX175/Detailed_results_20230429_022300_ncmes1_sims40_HILOX175.txt
###

## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2023-04-29T02:23Z.

Estimated speed: ~566 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 32 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 5/-31 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2023-04-29T02:23:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that this CME may affect STEREO A and OSIRIS-REx (glancing blow).  The leading edge or flank of the CME will reach STEREO A at 2023-05-02T00:54Z and OSIRIS-REx at 2023-05-02T19:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

The simulation also indicates that the CME may impact NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2023-05-02T03:57Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 3-5 (below minor to minor).

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information (CCMC DONKI)
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for April 19, 2023 - April 25, 2023
##
## Message Issue Date: 2023-04-26T21:53:33Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2023-04-19T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2023-04-25T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20230426-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at moderate levels during this reporting period with 1 M-class flare, 1 O-type CME, and 5 C-type CMEs (see details below). 

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the O-type CME first visible in SOHO imagery at 2023-04-21T18:12Z associated with the M1.7 flare which peaked at 2023-04-21T18:12Z, may reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2023-04-23T19:05Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index was 6-8 (moderate to severe). An ensemble simulation was performed for this CME with 32 members. For the ensemble, the CME was estimated to reach NASA missions near Earth between about 2023-04-23T10:51Z and 2023-04-24T11:38Z (average arrival 2023-04-23T19:36Z) for 100% of simulations. The ensemble-based forecast indicated that there was a 58% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 5-7 range (minor to strong). Full details of the modeled event at: https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-04-21_ncmes1_sims32_HILOX172/Detailed_results_20230421_203700_ncmes1_sims32_HILOX172.txt (see notifications 20230421-AL-002, 20230421-AL-003, and 20230422-AL-001).

Another C-type CME first visible in SOHO imagery at 2023-04-24T14:12Z is also estimated to reach NASA missions near Earth at 2023-04-27T07:48Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 4-6 (below minor to moderate). An ensemble was also performed for this CME with 24 members. For the ensemble, the CME is estimated to reach NASA missions near Earth between about 2023-04-27T01:06Z and 2023-04-27T11:02Z (average arrival 2023-04-27T06:19Z) for 87% of simulations.  The ensemble-based forecast indicates that there is a 97% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 4-6 range (below minor to moderate). Full details of the modeled event at:
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-04-24_ncmes1_sims24_HILOX173/Detailed_results_20230424_141200_ncmes1_sims24_HILOX173.txt (see notifications 20230424-AL-002 and 20230425-AL-001).

It was also estimated that the following CMEs are predicted to impact non-Earth locations:
CME Starting time  | Predicted Location/Mission Impacts (plus minus 7 hours)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------  
2023-04-21T06:24Z   Parker Solar Probe at 2023-04-23T04:24Z and Solar Orbiter at 2023-04-22T06:53Z (see notification 20230421-AL-001)
2023-04-21T18:12Z   OSIRIS-REx at 2023-04-24T22:44Z and STEREO A at 2023-04-23T18:24Z (see notifications 20230421-AL-002 and 20230421-AL-003)
2023-04-24T14:12Z   STEREO A at 2023-04-27T04:06Z (see notification 20230424-AL-002). 

Geomagnetic activity was at severe levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=8 for the reporting period. The highest Kp=8 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2023-04-23T18:00Z-21:00Z and 2023-04-24T03:00Z-06:00Z (see notifications 20230423-AL-011 and 20230424-AL-001). This severe geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 on 2023-04-23T17:00Z of the O-type CME mentioned above first visible at 2023-04-21T18:12Z (see notification 20230423-AL-006). This arrival also caused a strong compression of the magnetosphere. Simulations carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center indicated that the magnetopause separating magnetospheric and solar wind plasma was close to the geosynchronous orbit starting at 2023-04-23T19:15Z (see notifications 20230423-AL-008 and 20230423-AL-009). The arrival of this CME was also detected by the STEREO A IMPACT and PLASTIC data around 2023-04-23T14:00Z.

There was also a solar energetic particle event detected by STEREO A, SOHO, and GOES. The flux of 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A exceeded 10^(-1) pfu/MeV starting at 2023-04-23T13:58Z. The flux of one or more of the SOHO >15.8 MeV protons channels exceeded 10^(-1) pfu/MeV starting at 2023-04-23T17:28Z. The flux of GOES > 10 MeV protons exceeded 10 pfu starting at 2023-04-23T18:15Z (see notifications 20230423-AL-002, 20230423-AL-003, 20230423-AL-005, 20230423-AL-007, and 20230423-AL-010). This solar energetic particle event was associated with the arrival of the O-type CME mentioned above. The particle environment was somewhat elevated close to the end of 2023-04-21 with the eruption of the CME, but it crossed the different thresholds on the CME arrival time. The particle environment is back to nominal levels in all the locations. 

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period.

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been moderate this week due to the solar energetic particle event mentioned above.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2023-04-26T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2023-05-02T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low to moderate during the upcoming period. There are seven active regions present on the Earth's facing disk. The active regions 13288 (S22E13) and 13289 (N20E56) have currently been producing most of the C and B-class flaring activity and may continue to produce some activity in the next upcoming period. 

Geomagnetic activity is expected to be moderate for the upcoming week due to the expected arrival on 2023-04-27 of the C-type CME mentioned above and also the possible arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream at the end of 2023-04-26. Currently, GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux was above the threshold of 1000 pfu starting at 2023-04-26T12:35Z. These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt were associated with the arrival of the O-type CME mentioned above (see notifications 20230426-AL-001 and 20230426-AL-002).

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2023-04-19T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2023-04-25T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be at moderate levels throughout the outlook period. There are currently eight numbered Active Regions on the Earth-facing disk. Active Region 13282 (N11W10) produced both M-class flares observed during the reporting period. This region may continue to exhibit notable flaring activity during the outlook period. Additionally, an unnumbered Active Region visible on the eastern limb in STEREO A EUVI imagery near latitude S20 is expected to rotate onto the Earth-facing disk by 2023-04-20.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to be minor to moderate during the outlook period. The interplanetary shock detected at L1 by DSCOVR and ACE at 2023-04-18T13:19Z, possibly associated with the C-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2023-04-14T21:24Z (see notification 20230418-AL-001), may cause enhancement in the > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt during the first half of the outlook period.  Additionally, the combined arrival of S-type CMEs first seen in STEREO A COR2 at 2023-04-16T00:24Z and SOHO LASCO C2 at 2023-04-16T00:36Z may impact missions near Earth around 2023-04-20T10:56Z. The expected Kp range is 2-4 (low to below minor). Furthermore, there were two broad coronal dimming signatures seen near the central meridian centered around latitudes N22 and S03 at 2023-04-17T05:00Z and 2023-04-17T12:30Z, respectively, that did not appear to have created any detectable CMEs in available coronagraph imagery due to their location on the solar disk, but appear to be Earth-directed. It is possible we may see these arrival signatures at L1 in the beginning of the outlook period. Finally, there may be minor enhancement in geomagnetic activity in the second half of the outlook period due to the possible arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream associated with a coronal hole which reached the central meridian on 2023-04-18.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2023-04-12T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2023-04-18T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between minor to moderate levels for the upcoming week. There are currently five numbered active regions on the Earth-facing disk and two decayed numbered plage regions. Most notable of these regions is Active Region 13272 (S21E02) which produced three of the four M-class flares during this reporting period and may continue to produce higher level flaring throughout the week. A region visible on the eastern limb of the STEREO A-facing disk near latitude S25 may rotate onto the Earth-facing disk in the first half of the outlook period. 

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and moderate levels throughout the upcoming week. Effects from the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 on 2023-04-10 have begun to subside. This arrival was associated with the Interplanetary Shock detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 at 2023-04-09T21:57Z (see notification 20230410-AL-001). The arrival of this coronal hole high speed stream may have been combined with a weak transient event, and also was possibly detected by STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments on 2023-04-09. The >2.0 energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt may be enhanced during the outlook period due to the arrival of the aforementioned coronal hole high speed stream. Finally, there may be additional increases in geomagnetic activity during the outlook period from a coronal hole currently centered around S40W15 that may become geoeffective around 2023-04-14 and a coronal hole currently centered around N30W03 which may become geoeffective around 2023-04-15.

## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for March 29, 2023 - April 04, 2023
##
## Message Issue Date: 2023-04-05T20:25:01Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2023-03-29T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2023-04-04T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20230405-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity varied between moderate and high levels during this reporting period with 1 X-class flare, 3 M-class flares, 1 O-type CME, and 12 C-type CMEs (see details below).

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the following CMEs are predicted to impact non-Earth locations:

CME Starting time  | Predicted Location/Mission Impacts (plus minus 7 hours)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2023-03-30T08:00Z   OSIRIS-REx at 2023-04-04T15:24Z and Parker Solar Probe at 2023-03-31T19:08Z (see notification 20230330-AL-003)
2023-03-31T14:57Z   Parker Solar Probe at 2023-04-01T19:28Z (see notification 20230331-AL-002)
2023-03-31T17:53Z   Parker Solar Probe at 2023-04-02T04:31Z (see notification 20230401-AL-002)
2023-04-01T03:36Z   Parker Solar Probe at 2023-04-02T03:26Z and OSIRIS-REx at 2023-04-04T18:15Z, Solar Orbiter at 2023-04-02T00:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20230401-AL-001)
2023-04-03T08:00Z   Parker Solar Probe at 2023-04-05T14:02Z (see notification 20230403-AL-002)
2023-04-04T03:48Z   Parker Solar Probe at 2023-04-05T19:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20230404-AL-001)
2023-04-04T04:12Z   Parker Solar Probe at 2023-04-05T19:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20230404-AL-001)

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4.67 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=4.67 occurred during the synoptic period of 2023-03-31T03:00Z-06:00Z. This enhancement of geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream observed at DSCOVR and ACE at L1 on 2023-03-30.  

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt was enhanced at the beginning of this reporting period due to a threshold crossing during the previous reporting period beginning at 2023-03-27T00:25Z, caused by a coronal hole high speed stream which arrived on 2023-03-24 (see notifications 20230327-AL-001, 20230327-AL-002, and 20230329-AL-003). Energetic electron flux levels subsided on 2023-03-30 before a new threshold crossing of 1000 pfu occurred at 2023-03-31T18:15Z (see notifications 20230331-AL-001, 20230403-AL-001 and 20230405-AL-001). This separate elevation in energetic electron flux levels were likely caused by the arrival of a new coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 around 2023-03-30. The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux levels remained elevated above 1000 pfu for the rest of the reporting period.

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. The GOES >10 MeV protons were elevated above the background on 2023-03-30, possibly in association with an M5.4-class solar flare from AR 13256 located at S22W77 which peaked around 2023-03-30T07:24Z and associated C-type CME that was first visible in SOHO imagery at 2023-03-30T08:00Z.

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been minor to moderate this week due to the elevated energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2023-04-05T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2023-04-11T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary from low to moderate levels in the outlook period. There are currently three numbered Active Regions and four decayed plage regions on the Earth-facing disk. The most complex of these Active Regions, AR 13270 (S23W41), has a beta-gamma magnetic configuration and may exhibit notable flaring activity during the outlook period. An unnumbered active region seen in STEREO A EUVI imagery near latitude S30 may soon rotate onto the Earth-facing disk in the first half of the outlook period.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to be at low to minor levels during the outlook period. A small coronal hole centered around N10E45 is expected to cross the central meridian by 2023-04-08. The >2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt most recently crossed the threshold of 1000 pfu at 2023-03-31T18:15Z as mentioned above and is likely to remain elevated during the beginning part of the outlook period.

## Summary:

Multiple CMEs have been detected as follows:
1: S-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2023-03-31T09:36Z.

Estimated speed: ~391 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 25 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 103/23 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2023-03-31T09:36:00-CME-001

2: C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2023-03-31T14:57Z.

Estimated speed: ~819 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 45 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 119/35 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2023-03-31T14:57:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CMEs may impact Parker Solar Probe. The leading edge of the CMEs will reach Parker Solar Probe at 2023-04-01T19:28Z (plus minus 7 hours).

## Notes: 


SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux is above 1000 pfu starting at 2023-03-31T18:15Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are likely caused by a coronal hole high speed stream starting at 2023-03-30. The solar wind speed reached a maximum speed of approximately 650 km/s and is currently around 490 km/s.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2023-03-31T18:15:00-RBE-001.
